subject: Create IBM ConfigFile base directory
commitMessage:
Create IBM ConfigFile base directory

The ConfigFile upload fails when the /var/lib/obmc directory is not
available at BMC

This commit changes the base directory to /var/lib/bmcweb
The subdirectories for the configfiles and locks
are created under this new path

Migration strategy of this directory and files:
 This is IBM only feature, compiled under the IBM_MANAGEMENT_CONSOLE flag
 There is no system out yet which is running this code
 Internal IBM stake holders are in agreement with the changes

Tested by :
  1. Tested configfile upload on a BMC where the base directory is not
available
  2. Tested the configfile upload on a factory BMC. Verified it creates
     the base directories and the upload is successful
  3. Tested the configfile usecases for delete and delete-all
  4. Tested the acquire-lock functionality
  5. Ran lock unit test successfully

Signed-off-by: Sunitha Harish <sunharis@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ic3f5f5d0ba0b37950fd397ec835b4fa7babdaa9b

Patch Set 3:

Any solution to the meson install problem is welcome. Else can we go ahead with the code in the application file itself ?

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Any solution to the meson install problem is welcome. Else can we go ahead with the code in the application file itself ?

As per the meson documentation , add_install_script also accepts arguments.
so, you can pass the sharedstatedir variable from the meson.build file to your script, which by default as mentioned in documentation points to /var/lib and modify the script to something like

#!/bin/sh
mkdir -p $MESON_INSTALL_PREFIX/$1/ibm-management-console

where $1 would have sharedstatedir value. That should solve the issue.

meson does not seem to have empty directory creation at the moment, With that said, I am not really sure if maintaining a script in bmcweb only for creating directory would be the best way to solve this problem(its maintainers call though). IMO, Having these things in recipe is equally unsatisfactory as this solution.

I'm not following why this is a block.  If there's a bug in meson, go find it and fix it, and we'll backport the change into OpenBMC.  With that said, I find it really tough to believe this is truly a meson bug, as if it was, many other projects would be broken and uninstallable.

Patch Set 3:

A drive-by thought - the convention on Linux is put this kind of data in /var/lib/bmcweb (or a subdirectory of that so maybe /var/lib/bmcweb/ibm-foo).

Is now the right time to fix our unconventional use of /var/lib/obmc?

 > 
 > I have updated my observations after trying that solution. Please
 > check the further comments

I had a discussion with Adriana. The /var directory should be empty at build time, so we can’t create any files or directories at build time, it can be done only at runtime. The /var is mounted to a read-write directory when the BMC boots up. Its not an overlay.

The changes to create directories at the application layer here are good.

>  > 
>  > I have updated my observations after trying that solution. Please
>  > check the further comments
> 
> I had a discussion with Adriana. The /var directory should be empty at build time, so we can’t create any files or directories at build time, it can be done only at runtime. The /var is mounted to a read-write directory when the BMC boots up. Its not an overlay.
> 
> The changes to create directories at the application layer here are good.

Right. The /var/ dir is mounted on a writable volume. If the content of a file doesn't change, it can be in the rootfs, if the content of a file has a default value and changes at runtime, it can go to /etc/ since it's an overlay. If contents are just created at runtime, the application targets /var/ at runtime, which is wiped out during bmc factory reset.

Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> Ed you okay with this?

As a feature on the whole, not really.  We should have a single place of storing persistent data in the persistent data class.  The fact that this module has gone off and created their own special persistence files means that we can't handle upgrades/downgrades/schema changes properly, which, maybe is fine for the IBM requirements?

in terms of this patch, and the difference it brings, the folder being created needs permissions, and it needs to document the migration strategy in the commit message, even if it's "we don't support it, and will delete any files in the old folder structure".  As-is, systems that used the old folder are going to have files "disappear" on an upgrade.  If that's explicit and intentional, the files need to be deleted from disk.

If that's unintentional, I assume the files can be moved to the new folder, but either way, it needs documented in the commit message.

After that is done, this patchset looks fine.

I have already mentioned the below in my commit message.
"This commit moves the base directory to /var/lib/bmcweb
and creates the ibm-management-console directory as a base directory
for the configfiles and locks under the /var/lib/bmcweb path". I can improve this to mention more details.

When it comes to the migration strategy of this directory and files - This is IBM only feature; compiled under the IBM_MANAGEMENT_CONSOLE flag. There is no system out yet which is running this OpenBMC code. All systems are at our IBM lab, where we are handling this directory structure changes , as how normally a development process does. Our internal IBM stake holders are in agreement with the changes, which should be OK for this to go ahead.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 3e919b5857555e95d5348028bdc7393b9a1eca1a by Gunnar Mills
Why?  Shouldn't this be created as an install step?
The /var/ directory is empty by default, so if the application needs the sub-directories under that, it should create those directories

> The /var/ directory is empty by default, so if the application needs the sub-directories under that, it should create those directories

At.... install...time.  Not at runtime.

Also, it needs to set appropriate permissions on them.
New patchset still has not moved these to install time, although it looks like some permissions have been added.

Seems we need to identify why the obmc folder was not created, It should have been created in first place.

Few refrences are below

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/initrdscripts/obmc-phosphor-initfs.bb#L29

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/initrdscripts/files/whitelist#L10

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/initrdscripts/files/obmc-init.sh#L21

We should look at why this path was not created after boot.

Spoke with Adraiana on the same and seems the above references are to make sure that these files/directories persist across boot.

In this case, when the bmcweb is coming up, it needs to make sure that it has all the directories created and bmcweb can create the directory if it is not created.

I would suggest that not to use the /var/lib/obmc. Instead we can use something like /var/lib/bmcweb.

Ed, Do you see any concern if bmcweb creates the diretory as it is application specific directory and can't depend on the recipe to create/install the directory for bmcweb.

> Spoke with Adraiana on the same and seems the above references are to make sure that these files/directories persist across boot.
> 
> In this case, when the bmcweb is coming up, it needs to make sure that it has all the directories created and bmcweb can create the directory if it is not created.

No, if the directory doesn't exist, bmcweb can simply crash, as the code was not installed correctly.  Very similar to if /var/www/ doesn't exist.

> 
> I would suggest that not to use the /var/lib/obmc. Instead we can use something like /var/lib/bmcweb.

considering this is IBM specific, I'd much rather us use something like "ibm-manage-console" in the name.

> 
> Ed, Do you see any concern if bmcweb creates the diretory as it is application specific directory and can't depend on the recipe to create/install the directory for bmcweb.

bmcweb already depends on the recipe being used, so there's no change here.  You also don't need to do it in the recipe.

Ed, Can you please help to clarify:
1. Make change in recipe ? 
or 
2. Not to make change in recipe and do the directory creation in the existing function createSaveAreaPath in management_console_rest file ?
3. What I asked for in the first comment.  Please make it an install step.  This would generally be done in the meson file, and only done if ibm management console is enabled.

I was unaware that it can be done through install step, Thanks for the info.
meson.add_install_script("bash script to create the directory")

I tried using the install with install_subdir API and also the add_install_script. I was not successful in getting the empty directories created at BMC. May be i need this meson issue resolved ?
https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/2904

I was able to create empty directory under /usr/ path which is the MESON_INSTALL_PREFIX. Using the below instruction in the meson.build file:
 
 meson.add_install_script('include/ibm/create_dir.sh')

create_dir.sh:
#!/bin/sh
mkdir "${DESTDIR}/${MESON_INSTALL_PREFIX}/ibm-management-console"

Since the /usr path is read-only, creating the directory for writing configfiles in this parent directory will not work/is not correct.

I could not change the MESON_INSTALL_PREFIX to /var/lib path. 
Ed, can you please suggest a way here to change the install dir to /var/lib ?

A quick look at the meson documentation shows that localstatedir sets the /var directory.

https://mesonbuild.com/Builtin-options.html

Hi Ed, Earlier I had tried using this MESON_INSTALL_LOCALSTATEDIR path. After a bitbake, this does not create the directory under sysroot-destdir, the path which gets installed in the BMC. 

To get the new directories under the sysroot-destdir, i had to use the MESON_INSTALL_PREFIX which is the meson 'installation prefix'.

Thus asked you to suggest the code, which you were expecting to implement in the meson install phase. Can you please check and let me know how to achieve this ?

Can you make the summary 1 line and 50 characters ?
We follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ 

Whose 7 rules are: 
    Separate subject from body with a blank line
    Limit the subject line to 50 characters
    Capitalize the subject line
    Do not end the subject line with a period
    Use the imperative mood in the subject line
    Wrap the body at 72 characters
    Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

Thanks!
Done
Can we update this with what we know? Reference the meson issue? https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/7972
This isn't needed;  If the paths already exist, you will get an appropriate return code on line 204 that you can ignore.

This seems too lax. 
I would think similar permissions to 

~# ls -l bmcweb_persistent_data.json 
-rw-r-----    1 root     root           174 Sep 21 21:54 bmcweb_persistent_data.json

Directory will have drwxr-xr-x similar to other directories 
# cd /var/lib/
# ls -lrt
drwxr-xr-x    3 root     root          4096 Nov 24 05:23 bmcweb
Sure. I would still think we might want to lock this down more?
I dont see a reason to deviate from the other directory permissions which are set under /var/lib
Agree with Gunnar.  This is a private file, it should have private permissions.

This is the permission to the directory. 
File permissions are : -rw-r--r--

Just adding a "me too" I think 600 for file permissions make a lot of sense from a process isolation POV going forward.  I found several files in /var/lib on my laptop from popular well known packages that create their files with 600 permissions so I don't expect there are any best practices that indicate files in /var/lib should be group/world readable.

For the parent directory I don't have any preference, but I did find directories with 700 permissions too, so it isn't as if we are breaking any norms or best practices by using 700 on the parent directory.

Why are the unit tests interacting with the filesystem at all?  I would expect some mocks for the filesystem instead of trying to rely on temp directories.

With that said, this code is no worse, but I'd like to see some discussion on why this was done originally, so when we get to more broad unit tests in bmcweb, we can have a generalized solution for this kind of thing.
Sure Ed
I still don't see this addressed?

Gunnar. Its a future work. There are other places where the UT is done by creating files and dirs at tmp path. There needs to be a discussion for a different approach and every place a rework is needed. Along with that this part of the code also can be reworked.

Probably best to explain this in the initial reply. 

Is the plan to do this in a later commit?

What I don't like here, is that it's covering up the root cause.  The root of the problem here is that you're using the filesystem in a "unit" test, which is a general anti-pattern.  IMO, commit moves in the wrong direction by simply covering the issue up with a temp directory.  I'd like to see some discussion on this "future work" and how this commit enables the future work, instead of going further down the incorrect path.

" I'd like to see some discussion on why this was done originally...."

Was what I wrote a week ago, and I still haven't seen that.

I did not intend to cover up any comments/root cause. But did not understand that there should be a root cause solution for using the /tmp filesystem before this commit goes ahead.

The community email does not have any replies yet.
I have other priority work items to work on, so I will not be able to rework on this comment here in this commit for couple of more months.

>Why are the unit tests interacting with the filesystem at all?  I would expect some mocks for the filesystem instead of trying to rely on temp directories.

It depends on case to case basis.

If we have some code which reads from the file and populate the in memory objects from it, then it is needed otherwise not.

Eg: Restoring of Dbus objects from the file system.

However in this case I don't see that we are doing something else apart from creating the directory using std::filesyetem API..

Our intent should not be to test the file system API, hence this test case doesn't make sense.

Done.

Pretty sure you don't want your folder to be executable.

Huh?  owner_all seems right to me.
Per Posix, execute permission for a directory allows searches through that directory: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/perms and
The management_console_rest.hpp code uses std::filesystem_directory_iterator which requires X (search) permission.
Ack
